By 1950 the Mtape network** for American education served 34
member stations and had grown in service and stature until it was no longer
an experiment. It was becoming a large scale activity which was out¬
growing its facilities and financial structure* Dean Wilbur Schramm of
the University of Illinois formally proposed a plan whereby the NAEB net¬
work could locate at the University of Illinois and could be financed and
supported by a series of special grants in addition to specific contribu¬
tions of housing and personnel which the University of Illinois would be
willing to make. Subsequently the network was moved to the University
of Illinois and space and personnel for its operation were initially donated
by the University* In 1951, the initial grant for expanded operation of
the Network, including duplicators and other capital equipment, and the
establishment of a permanent Headquarters, wiih a full-time Executive
Director, was received from the W. K. Kellogg Foundation,
The terms of the Kellogg grant provided that, although complete
support would be provided for Headquarters over the five-year life of
this first grant, the Network operation would have to be set up on a basis
which would lead to eventual self-support through member stations paying
for the program service provided by the Network. This transition to self-
support for the Network was accomplished in four years; by July I. 1955
the Network became completely self-supporting. Since that time the Net*
